body: Any comments for corrections, additions or deletions are welcomed.  MLContext guide to be addressed separately.
cc @asurve @mboehm7

thanks @gweidner - this looks great and it already revealed a shortcoming of our transformdecode: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1018.

Some additional comments for further improvement:
- creating frames: you might want to rephrase the default schema a bit: schema="_" resolves to a string schema and if no schema is specified, the default is "_"
- casting: frame to matrix is a best effort operation, which tries to parse doubles - if there are for example strings that cannot be parsed, this operation produces errors.
- schema impliciations on casting: as.frame(matrix) produces a double schema, as.scalar(frame) produces of scalar of value type given by the frame schema.
- transformdecode: please mention that not all transformation are reversible (recoding, dummy coding and pass-through are reversible, i.e., subject to transformdecode, whereas binning, missing value imputation, and omit are not)
- transformapply: please add that this function applies existing meta data. In order to show the relationship to transformencode, you can mention that transformencode := build+apply, whereas transformapply := apply
- meta data as frames: please highlight (maybe in the transformencode example) that the meta data is simply a frame and hence all operations and read/write can similarly be applied to the meta data too.
- toString: it would be good to either extend the description of toString (to support frame inputs) or include it under frames too (its included in the examples but the tables are the actual language reference)
Thank you very much @mboehm7  for your input and time!  I will incorporate each item and push new commits to this PR.

Previously jodd provided through spark version 1.4.1:
![jodd-dependency](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12058879/19202291/76f2fc26-8c86-11e6-9056-3cc8516b75bf.png)

Changing to newer spark version (1.5+) resulted in compilation error so also added maven dependency.  Used 'provided' scope so not bundled and no license update necessary.
thanks @gweidner - the import of jodd was actually a bug and is now fixed - I guess we can completely remove this dependency now.

Thank you @mboehm7 for catching that!  My bad for not recognizing as I thought it was intended as part of optimization for [SYSTEMML-557].  I've removed the dependency and rebased this branch to pick up the latest changes.  Also successfully built with distribution profile locally on my dev system.

Thank you very much @gweidner for willing to  volunteer on documenting this work, really appreciate it.
It looks good for me. I have minor comments if you willing.
- Indexing Frames
  Please use B, C, D, E instead of G, H, I, J in right indexing assignments to show relevance. Please put  left/right indexing sub-section for those examples.
- Casting Frames:
  Please be consistent with inA/inputA, please describe what is inA/inputA etc
  Provide an additional statement to write with different format csv, text, binary 
- Manipulating Frames:
  Not sure how length() is going to work, never used.
- Thanks
There were unit test failures in [PR build 717](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/717/) - at one time I had them all passing for spark 1.6.

Some of the tests are new since I last investigated Spark 1.6/2.0.  One example below:

Thank you @deroneriksson for reducing some of the javadoc warnings.  I compared build output and saw a reduction from 683 to 653 javadoc warnings.  Also no longer saw javadoc warnings for MLContext.java, MLContextProxy.java, MLMatrix.java and MLOutput.java.  Most of the changes also involved adding descriptions to the existing parameters which is good.

Note I observed the following warnings for DMLScript.java
[WARNING] C:\git\incubator-systemml\src\main\java\org\apache\sysml\api\DMLScript.java:512: warning - @return tag has no arguments.
[WARNING] C:\git\incubator-systemml\src\main\java\org\apache\sysml\api\DMLScript.java:919: warning - @return tag has no arguments.

Can these 2 also be removed for DMLScript,java since it's part of the change set?

@gweidner Thank you for looking at this. I think the default javadoc warnings occur for public methods but not for other scopes such as private. I have been looking for javadoc warnings using the following command, which only generates javadocs for the api package (by excluding all the other packages at the same level as the api package):

```
mvn javadoc:javadoc -DexcludePackageNames=org.apache.sysml.conf:org.apache.sysml.debug:org.apache.sysml.hops:org.apache.sysml.lops:org.apache.sysml.parser:org.apache.sysml.runtime:org.apache.sysml.udf:org.apache.sysml.utils:org.apache.sysml.yarn
```

When I run that command, no warnings occur.

I agree that it would be nice to remove all of those auto-generated comments from the private methods. Do you think that should also be addressed in this PR?
@gweidner BTW, how are you generating the javadocs (to see the "683 to 653" numbers)?

I saw the warnings for mvn build with -Pdistribution and redirected the output for comparison:
mvn clean package -DskipTests=true -Pdistribution > build_log2.txt

Since private methods, they don't need to be addressed in this PR.
LGTM
Thank you @asurve for feedback.  I've incorporated all comments.

I've refreshed my gh-pages so the latest changes can be viewed at http://gweidner.github.io/incubator-systemml/dml-language-reference.html.  Summary of changes:
1) Rephrased default schema in Creating Frames section.
2) Added description in casting frames for potential errors since Java's Double.parseDouble() used internally.
3) Expanded all transform-related sections including adding table showing supported transform-types for encode, decode, apply.
4) Added toString description to Manipulating Frames table.
5) Clarified Indexing Frames example.
6) Added statements to Casting example.
7) Removed length from Manipulating Frames table although it seemed to work at least for one simple scenario.
Based on additional input, I've integrated toString, nrow, ncol function descriptions for frame's into existing matrix function tables (15 and 3).  Removed section/table 'Manipulating Frames'.

I've pushed new commit which updates both Creating Frames and transformencode sections to incorporate additional input.  Tabs were added to show impact of extra white space before column name in header.  Verified the given transform specifications matched the corresponding headers by running testHomesRecodeColnamesSingleNodeCSV with this example data.

I've refreshed my gh-pages so the latest changes can be viewed at http://gweidner.github.io/incubator-systemml/dml-language-reference.html.

I've pushed new commit as work-around to prevent the ClassCastException for DataFrameVectorFrameConversionTest and DataFrameVectorScriptTest.  Each of the failures for those 2 suites (16 each suite) were identical where only the "ID" test cases were failing with:
java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.Integer incompatible with java.lang.Double
which was raised when calling df.first() in FrameRDDConverterUtils.dataFrameToBinaryBlock as part of intializing clen.
The work-around simply casts the integer to double when creating the index column for the Row although not sure if this should be handled within converter (e.g., for schema, observed Int mapped to DataType.LongType).
Both tests suites pass on my local Eclipse environment.  The MLContext failures will be looked at next.  Note this push should reduce the failures from 46 to 14.  PR build in progress:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/728/

The PR build completed with DataFrameVectorScript and DataFrameVectorFrameConversion tests passing with 14 failures remaining as expected in MLContextTest and MLContextFrameTest.  Pushed new commit for MLContextTest to resolve it's failures (10) where each one had 
java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.Double incompatible with java.lang.Integer
at RDDConverterUtils.dataFrameToBinaryBlock(RDDConverterUtils.java:290
    long rlen = tmp.count();  //tmp is JavaRDD<Row>
Note this latest commit will reduce the failures from 14 to 4.  PR build in progress:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/729/
This looks ok as an initial prototype cut. This change set really should include some explicit documentation on the limitations of the current implementation.

In general, I think it is great that we are continuing to think about how to solve these kinds of problems in the DSL.  For this particular case pushing down for-loops, I'd like to step back and discuss other possible ideas.

In this case, we are assuming that we need to push the actual loop down into DML.  Overall, I'm concerned that the current prototype could end up causing problems due to users not understanding what subset of Python could be used within the function.  As an alternative, what if we instead only defined the graph of operations for a single iteration, and then evaluated that graph repeatedly in a Python for-loop?  For example:

``` r
// Starting values
V = .... // some input data converted to a SystemML Matrix
W = sml.random.uniform(size=(m, k))
H = sml.random.uniform(size=(k, n))

// Train in a loop
for i in range(0, 200):
  H = H * dot(W.transpose(), V)/dot(W.transpose(), dot(W, H))
  W = W * dot(V, H.transpose())/dot(W, dot(H, H.transpose()))
  sml.eval(W, H)  // Eval the graph so that W & H are evaluated, starting with their previous values

// Now, W & H have the final values in SystemML matrix objects, which we can convert to NumPy:
W = W.toNumPy()
H = H.toNumPy()
```

We could also define the graph of operations for a single iteration outside of the for loop:

``` r
// Starting values
V = .... // some input data converted to a SystemML Matrix
W = sml.random.uniform(size=(m, k))
H = sml.random.uniform(size=(k, n))

// Graph of operations for a single iteration
H = H * dot(W.transpose(), V)/dot(W.transpose(), dot(W, H))
W = W * dot(V, H.transpose())/dot(W, dot(H, H.transpose()))

// Train in a loop
for i in range(0, 200):
  sml.eval(W, H)  // Eval the graph so that W & H are evaluated, starting with their previous values

// Now, W & H contain their final values in SystemML matrix objects, which we can convert to NumPy, for example:
W = W.toNumPy()
H = H.toNumPy()
```

Thoughts?

All tests are now passing at [PR build 730](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/730/).  However, the latest commit for MLContextFrameTest involved changing schema since Long, Double, Boolean were not being converted for input type DataFrame.

@dusenberrymw @frreiss Thanks for your feedback.

We should support following two approaches as they are not mutually exclusive:

A. "the graph of operations for a single iteration, and then evaluated that graph repeatedly in a Python for-loop": This is currently supported without PR 270.

Pros: 
- Simple and user-friendly API especially to the Spark users who are familiar with lazy evaluation.

Cons: 
- Doesnot exploit loop optimization mentioned in the VLDB paper. Imran said that this approach didnot yield satisfactory performance for NMF script.

B. Push-down of loop via parallelize (this PR):

Pros: 
- Exploits loop optimization.
- If we plan reimplement our DML algorithms using Python DSL and ship it as part of mllearn, we should take this approach as it would have same performance as invoking the algorithm from commandline.

Cons:
- Limited by what PyDML supports -> It important to note that this is limitation of PyDML (and by transitive property DML) not parallelize construct. As we add more functionality to SystemML, this limitation will be addressed over time without a single line of change in parallelize construct.

May be I am missing something, but the "graph of operations for a single iteration outside of the for loop" option will not work as expected, you had already evaluated the operation during the first iteration. The remaining iteration will turn out to be "no op".

From API point of view, I would go with Mike's suggestions. The decorators are not used in general as part of APIs. At least I have not seen any. In my opinion, this will add a level complexity that many data scientist may not like deal with.

Just to be clear, then we will be making conscious choice that our Python API will:
- not be able to exploit any loop optimizations and 
- be significantly slower than simply converting the code to PyDML and invoking it from commandline.

Yeah that's a good breakdown of the possible options.  I should have clarified it before, but the code snippets I gave don't necessarily work, but reflect different possible designs and what they might look like in practice.

"It important to note that this is limitation of PyDML (and by transitive property DML) not parallelize construct." -> Yes, you are technically correct that this is a limitation of PyDML.  The problem I was identifying is just that -- a user of this parallelize construct would have to know the exact subset of Python that would work with PyDML, and any deviation from it would cause errors.  Thus, although we are allowing the user to literally use Python, in reality, we are forcing them to learn which subset of Python corresponds to the underlying PyDML.

With regards to "Imran said that this approach did not yield satisfactory performance for NMF script", the problem was not that the performance was slightly unsatisfactory, but rather that it was essentially broken.  Evaluation of `H` was quick as it should be, but then the subsequent evaluation of `W` took over an hour to finish, despite using almost the same operations.  This occurred when the graph was constructed within the loop and then executed once at the end.  I would suggest we first explore the root cause of that issue.  Once we figure out that issue, the remaining step would be to identify the magnitude of the performance improvements gained via loop optimizations.

Regarding the graph of operations outside of the for loop, yes that won't work today (noted above -- should have added that to the original post).  It represents another possible design, where the idea would be to define what the operations would be, starting with an initial set of values, and then allow for that graph to be executed as many times as desired.  Therefore, we start with initial values of `H` and `W`, then define update operations, then evaluate a single set of update steps repeatedly within the loop.  Basically, this would be similar to a TensorFlow style.

If Imran's concern is about the decorator, maybe we could think about going back to making the iteration a (set of) special function(s) like `sml.iterate(...)`? 
This way the user wouldn't have to define her own function (`def push_down_loop(inputs, outputs)`) where for me it is not clear right now if the function signature is unrestricted or if I could annotate arbitrary functions with @sml.parallelize.
For convenience it might also be possible to inspect the closure of a `sml.iterate(...)` function and set inputs automatically? Not sure about the output handling though...
eval(H,W) did not have any effect on the calculation of W. It still takes one hour.
Checking if the 4 cast exceptions for MLContextFrameTest similar issue as [SYSTEMML-956](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-956) fixed in #257 since indexing used in test script.

Ok, so it looks at this point like this PR does not actually fix the bug that it's associated with (SYSTEMML-1043). But it does represent a useful prototype developer API that future work could build on. How about if we open a new JIRA of type "improvement" to cover something like "initial support for pushing down the body of a function from Python DSL" and associate this change set with that JIRA? Then we can do something more simple and stable to cover SYSTEMML-1043.

@asurve I've fixed the four MLContextFrame tests with recent push that reverts the previous change for MLContextFrameTest and includes overloaded method in FrameRDDConverterUtils to incorporate schema information when converting to JavaRDD<Row>.  This approach is similar to updated FrameConverterTest from PR #223.
LGTM. Thank you @gweidner for adding Frame support to our documentation. Great job!
Can an Admin verify this patch?

Note for the empty required reporter field, I started typing my JIRA name which matched/filled-in.  I don't think it can be part of the submit to get filled in automatically as done when clicking JIRA 'Create' button.

I will merge this. Thank you @gweidner.

@frreiss @mboehm7 @bertholdreinwald @prithvirajsen 
What is the status of this PR?

copy from the dev list discussion - (2) and (3) are relevant to this PR:

1) Escaping: transformencode, transformdecode, and transformapply do not remove quotes to provide easy to understand semantics. If users want to match strings with different escaping policies to the same entry it's the user's responsibility to handle the unquoting. The nice side effect is that transformencode/transformapply and transformdecode are truly inverse operations, at least for reversible transformations like recoding and dummy coding.

2) Metadata frames: The schema for meta data frames is a string column per original column where each transformation type has its special serialization format. For example, for recoding, we serialize distinct {token}{delim}{code} (one entry per row). The reason why we use the quote-aware splitting on parsing this meta data is a best effort to handle cases where {delim} occurs inside the quoted token. A simply splitting on {delim} (as done in the "fix" by PR 274) would fail in this situation.

3) Solution: We could, however, simply flip the serialization format to {code}{delim}{token} which allows splitting on the first occurrence of {delim} because {code} is guaranteed not to include {delim}. Note that this would loose binary backwards compatibility to existing meta data frames though.

1. I don't believe we are suggesting to remove quotes. If we are following RFC 4180 based string format, then input coming from any source to be converted to RC 4180 based string format before any processing should occur. This will avoid exception if string is not compliant to RFC 4180 based format. We may have at least three options:  
   a. Make input string compliant to RFC 4180 format within code by escaping quotes etc. (No burden on user, but we need to be consistent to avoid different output based on input source.  
   b. Ask user (programmer) to put data in RFC 4180 based string format (Either through some utility we add in SystemML but user will leverage this utility on needed input data. (User may not be happy with, as they have to do additional steps)  
   c.  Output error message and exit processing (Again user may not be happy with)   
2. We know limitation of fix which is documented in code. Its unicode which may occur in original string (token), very uncommon scenario, but possible. 
3. WRT backward compatibility of existing meta data frames. Are these meta data frames in SystemML earlier released code? File based transform generates such meta data frames?

-Arvind

Let's keep this Jira and the discussion on the mailing list separate although the points raised in the discussion cause this issue here. 

Keep in mind that this issue only came about as strings where ingested that do NOT comply with the RFC spec.

I like the suggestion of switching to {code}{delim}{token} as it provides a more robust solution independent of the outcome of the discussion and the risk of people having the unicode delimiter in their string. In the code however, I would still not use the split.csv() but the much simpler strIndex(delim) because (1) we are only looking for 1 split, and (2) in this part of the code we do not care about the format of the token but only want the token. Quote-awareness etc. is dealt with in other parts of the system, and would only introduce unnecessary processing here.

As persisting the meta data frames were not released prior, we do not have to worry about backward compatibility.

Arvind, you should add the points a., b., and c. to the discussion in the mailing list.

I tried this with the example at [SYSTEMML-1077](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1077)
But I run it using the CP mode and print a part of the the matrix to make sure its not optimized away.

Program:

``` r
N = 2
C = 3
Hin = 10
Win = 10
f = 2
stride = 2
X = matrix(0, rows=N, cols=C*Hin*Win)
out = max_pool(X, input_shape=[N,C,Hin,Win], pool_size=[f,f], stride=[stride,stride], padding=[0,0])

print(toString(out[1:2,1:2]))
```

Works for me.
This fixes the issues with the two simple examples given in SYSTEMML-1076 & SYSTEMML-1077.  I'm running a modified LeNet network now to make sure there are no other regressions, and I'll report back.

Alright, this appears to have fixed those two specific issues.  I say we merge this, and we should also write some test cases as well that cover these two issues.  The Jenkins tests also passed for this PR: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/817/.

@asurve First of all, I really appreciate you putting so much effort in this PR, but I will have to give a -1.

I would highly recommend:
1. Writing wrappers in Scala for uniformity.
2. Using new MLContext because the old one is going to get deprecated.
3. Maximizing code reuse by deriving from BaseSystemMLClassifier or BaseSystemMLRegressor (or you can add a new Base class).

The above 3 points simplifies the integration with Python wrappers (i.e. mllearn - supports not just DataFrame but also NumPy/SciPy/Pandas DF) and will also help in maintaining the wrappers. For each algorithm, the core logic rests in two methods:
- `def getTrainingScript(isSingleNode:Boolean):(Script, String, String)`
- `def getPredictionScript(mloutput: MLResults, isSingleNode:Boolean): (Script, String)`

@niketanpansare @lresende @bertholdreinwald 

Here are some issues to be aware of with this approach:

1) Binding to the "post-integration-test" phase of the maven lifecycle.
The maven standard is to have build artifacts with the "package" phase of the maven lifecycle.

2) All other artifacts (besides main jar, sources jar, and javadoc jar) use the assembly plugin to create them. This uses exec-maven-plugin to execute python, which is a totally different pathway. It also means that if you don't have python installed, you can't build this artifact.

3) The other artifacts contain their LICENSEs at src/assembly/*. This artifact has its LICENSE at src/main/python/. This spreads build information to different locations rather than keeping it localized in src/assembly.

4) If you run "mvn post-integration-test -P distribution -DskipTests", this artifact does not end up in the target directory like a normal artifact. It ends up in src/main/python/dist. This is not standard.

5) As a result of 4, if you do a "mvn clean", this artifact does not get deleted. Not being able to clean the artifact is confusing to maven users. Also, it can typically lead to artifacts that aren't built correctly.

6) If I build, the artifact generated is called "systemml-incubating-0.11.0.dev1.tar.gz". However, all the other artifacts in target are called "systemml-0.12.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT*". This means the version number for this artifact must not be coming from the pom. This makes it hard to maintain.

7) What is "dev1"? Is that a python standard? I do not understand what "dev1" means.

8) The "systemml-0.11.0.dev6.tar.gz" that was on pypi contained the "SystemML.jar" in it at systemml/systemml-java/. This "systemml-incubating-0.11.0.dev1.tar.gz" is 23K and does not contain the systemml jar file. Is it supposed to contain the SystemML jar file like it did before?

9) If the artifact is supposed to contain the SystemML jar file, then the LICENSE needs to be updated to reflect that it contains the antlr runtime and wink dependencies in it. If it is not supposed to contain the SystemML jar file, then it is fine.

Thanks @deroneriksson  for detailed comments. I would highly appreciate if you could help with issues 1, 5, 6, 8 and 9.

> 1) Binding to the "post-integration-test" phase of the maven lifecycle.
> The maven standard is to have build artifacts with the "package" phase of the maven lifecycle.

Yes, I could not find an easy way to ensure that SystemML.jar is created before the `generate-python-package` is invoked in package phase. 

> 2) All other artifacts (besides main jar, sources jar, and javadoc jar) use the assembly plugin to create them. This uses exec-maven-plugin to execute python, which is a totally different pathway. It also means that if you don't have python installed, you can't build this artifact.

That is correct. The profile `distribution` now requires that python is installed because SystemML python package is now a part of the distribution.

> 3) The other artifacts contain their LICENSEs at src/assembly/*. This artifact has its LICENSE at src/main/python/. This spreads build information to different locations rather than keeping it localized in src/assembly.

This was to address the issue raised by Apache mentors, they explictly wanted the LICENSE to be included in the root folder of tgz. @lresende : Can you please double-check this ?

> 4) If you run "mvn post-integration-test -P distribution -DskipTests", this artifact does not end up in the target directory like a normal artifact. It ends up in src/main/python/dist. This is not standard.

That is python's standard location for building the artifact. I understand here we have to chose whether to follow maven standard location or python standard location and I am fine with either.

> 5) As a result of 4, if you do a "mvn clean", this artifact does not get deleted. Not being able to clean the artifact is confusing to maven users. Also, it can typically lead to artifacts that aren't built correctly.

Good point. 

> 6) If I build, the artifact generated is called "systemml-incubating-0.11.0.dev1.tar.gz". However, all the other artifacts in target are called "systemml-0.12.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT*". This means the version number for this artifact must not be coming from the pom. This makes it hard to maintain.

Good catch. We need to update the setup.py to get 0.12.0

> 7) What is "dev1"? Is that a python standard? I do not understand what "dev1" means.

Yes.

> 8) The "systemml-0.11.0.dev6.tar.gz" that was on pypi contained the "SystemML.jar" in it at systemml/systemml-java/. This "systemml-incubating-0.11.0.dev1.tar.gz" is 23K and does not contain the systemml jar file. Is it supposed to contain the SystemML jar file like it did before?

Yes, the new tgz should have same layout as systemml-0.11.0.dev6.tar.gz.

> 9) If the artifact is supposed to contain the SystemML jar file, then the LICENSE needs to be updated to reflect that it contains the antlr runtime and wink dependencies in it. If it is not supposed to contain the SystemML jar file, then it is fine.

LGTM. Thanks Nakul.
